comments:
Starting with 3.1M5A when loading the application, Hibernate is throwing a
ClassNotFoundException because it cannot find a sax parser.  The sax parser does
exist in the requirements for the plug-in.

This same setup worked using 3.1M4.

I will attach a zip file with a set of plug-ins that illustrates this problem.

Created an attachment (id=18490)
plug-in environment

Run the test case in gov.nasa.ensemble.core.tests.hibernateSaxFailure to
reproduce the bug.
Are running your target with a jdk 1.4.2
The attached zip file does not seem to have any content?

running with jdk 1.5

each contain 1+ plug-ins that together compromises the environment.

This is a problem with hibernate.  It is packaging xml-apis.jar which contains 
JAXP (javax.xml.* etc.) packages.  Eclipse assumes a 1.4.1 or higher VM which 
includes the JAXP packages.  The conflicting JAXP libraries is causing the 
ClassCastException.

One thing that did change for M5 is that we now delegate to the boot classpath 
after we have searched the Eclipe's delegation model.  This allows us to 
replace packages outside of the "java.*" packages that are included with the 
VM with classes supplied from plugins.  This change has caused hibernate to 
start failing because it now loads the javax.xml classes from it's internal 
xml-apis.jar library.

Jeff, do we need a setting to specify old style boot classpath delegation?  
(i.e always search the boot classpath first for all resources)

Seems like we might need some advice from the plugin here.  The hibernate 
plugin has to indicate that it needs to consult the bootloader first.  Or we 
need some sort of package exclusion list (e.g., the bundle says that it should 
not load its own P1, P2, ...).

alternatively the offending packages could be removed from the hibernate plugin.

A parallel bug report should be logged with hibernate so they can consider 
updating their deployment.
*** Bug 86666 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

(In reply to comment #10)
> A parallel bug report should be logged with hibernate so they can consider 
> updating their deployment.
In our project we are also using hibernate (and a lot of other libraries by the
way).. but it is not hibernates that bugs but the SWT libraries. 
The same project works well with the M4.

From some debugging trial I have seen that the 
META-INF/services/javax.xml.parsers.DocumentBuilderFactory
was found from the classLoader.
The first line inside is : org.apache.xerces.jaxp.DocumentBuilderFactoryImpl
However when loaded by the class loader the class is not the expected one...

Removing all the XML related libraries leads to an error similar to comment #8.

Hi,

Im the author of that plugin and I just found this bug entry.

I was pretty convinced something had changed between M4 and M5 on the 
classloading aspect - it also plays similar tricks with JBossIDE ,)


I can tell that I used many hours finding out why this issued occurs and im 
happy to see an explanation.

We will repackage the plugin to avoid this feature/bug.

Notice that due to this and other more fundamental issue with certain VMs, the 
classloading behaviour in M6 is being reverted to always consult the parent 
(typically boot) loader first.  Even for non-java.* classes.  This issue is 
still being worked out in the OSGi community and we await the outcome.

Sorry for the inconvenience that this has caused many of you.  The direction 
was good but some unforseen issues came up.

The osgi R4.0 spec behavior that caused this problem is implemented however it
is not on by default. 
See bug 93343 comment #21.
